The rich functionalities of platform molecules derived from the lignocellulosic deconstruction stream prompt their upgrading into valuable molecules and in particular into N-containing ones. Heterogeneous copper catalysts properly tailored with the right choice of the support, can effectively promote the amination of γ-valerolactone into the corresponding N-alkyl-pyrrolidinone or N-alkyl-pyrrolidines. The acidic properties and the copper phase morphology and dispersion are critical aspects to be investigated to address the reaction selectivity. The proposed transformation allows to obtain nitrogen derivatives that can find application as green solvents or as scaffolds for the chemical synthesis. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Green solvents Copper catalysts Platform molecules Lactams Acidic properties Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Platform molecules derived from the lignocellulosic biomass stream represent a valuable and variable pool of chemical structures that besides the energy and commodities-driven purposes, can be exploited for the synthesis of valuable chemicals. Actually the conversion of lignocellulosic derived platform molecules into both oxygenated and non-oxygenated biofuels has been extensively investigated due to their potential abundancy [1]. On the other hand, the intrinsic rich-functionality features of woody biomass give the opportunity to design attractive strategies for the upgrading of platform molecules into valuable structures, especially nitrogen-containing ones, a class of widespread diffused chemicals with application in diverse industrial sectors both as molecular scaffold for products and as solvent [2]. One of the main objectives and challenges presented by green chemistry is to reduce or replace the use of hazardous substances and processes. In particular, solvents are ubiquitous substances involved in the chemical industry with a broad range of applications. In recent times, solvent emissions or usage of harmful chemical substances has been limited by environmental legislation [3]. As a consequence, the academic and industrial field has grown the interest into find green alternatives or technologies to replace toxic, non-renewable N-containing solvents and chemicals. In this regards, bio-derived substances obtained from renewable biomass feedstock could be an excellent alternative. N-Methylpyrrolidinone (NMP) is a polar aprotic solvent extensively used in pharmaceutical and chemical industrial processes and formulations. However, it is reported in the candidate list of substances of very high concern due to its toxicity and reprotoxicity [4,5], thus making its replacement highly desirable [6,7]. N-alkyl-5-methyl-2-pyrrolidinones (NAPO) has showed to be an attractive alternative to NMP to be used as low toxicity industrial solvents. These compounds can be synthetized through reductive amination of levulinic acid (LA), ethyl levulinate (EL) or GVL using mostly noble metal based heterogeneous catalysts. Moreover, pyrrolidine ring is one of the most used nitrogen-containing heterocycles employed in the medicinal chemistry field to obtain compounds for the treatment of human diseases. Pyrrolidine appears to be a ubiquitous and versatile scaffold found in molecules that exhibit a wide variety of biological activities. Particularly, they are useful to synthetize compounds that have anti-cancer, anti-microbial properties and are active for the treatment of metabolic diseases [8]. It is also found in many other pharmaceuticals such as procyclidine and bepridil [9]. The combination of a reductive amination step on levulinic acid, followed by a deoxygenation one, is a convenient approach to synthetize pyrrolidinones and/or pyrrolidines. ໿However, while significant efforts have been made for the synthesis of N-substituted methyl-2-pyrrolidones in the presence of H2 as reducing agent by the reductive amination of LA, the production of N-substituted pyrrolidines (NAPE) have been hardly addressed. In the literature, few examples reporting the synthesis of pyrrolidine starting from LA can be found and they mainly rely on the use of homogeneous catalysis [9–11]. Conversely to its precursor LA, GVL is more prone to react with heterogeneous supported non-noble metal catalysts [12,13]. In fact, its physico-chemical properties make it a stable but at the same time reactive compound. Therefore, it can be a suitable starting material to synthetize a wide variety of chemicals. Besides, lactamization of lactones with amine is an appropriate way to produce lactams. We already studied a simple method for the heterogeneous catalytic synthesis of N‑butyl‑5-methylpyrrolidinone and N‑butyl‑5-methylpyrrolidine by using supported copper based catalysts prepared with the Chemisorption-Hydrolysis method (CH) (Scheme 1 ) [14]. Taking in mind that the presence of acidic and basic sites at the support surface can play a key role in promoting and maintaining high copper dispersion, besides conventional oxide supports, hydroxyapatite (HAP), a less conventional material in catalysis, has been selected for this study. HAP is a versatile inorganic material that can be easily synthesized in laboratory and can be also obtained from natural resources (biological sources or wastes, such as mammalian bones, marine or aquatic sources, e.g., fish bone and fish scale, shell sources, e.g., cockle, clam, eggshell, and seashell, and plants and algae) [15]. HAP possesses several interesting properties that vary with the preparation method and in particular with the Ca/P molar ratio of the used precursors in the synthesis. It is possible to vary the Ca/P ratio of HAP in the range 1.55–1.72, with 1.67 the value of stoichiometric hydroxyapatite. The Ca/P value can be considered a descriptor of the amphoteric properties of HAP surface [16]. Other peculiar properties of HAP are related to its ability to form solid solution and to be prone to Ca2+ exchange. The mobility of Ca2+ ions allows an easy substitution with other bivalent and trivalent metal species that remain very stably in HAP framework [17–19]. Then, the intrinsic characteristics of HAP combined with the amphoteric character of the surface make the possibility of obtaining functionalized materials suitable to be utilized in a wide fan of applications. In particular, HAP has emerged as an effective catalytic material for various organic and environmental catalytic reactions [20,21]. Actually, there are no evidence in the literature concerning the use of HAP supported copper catalysts prepared with CH method for the preparation of N-containing heterocycles, in particular lactames and pyrrolidines. In the present work we would like to propose a CuO/HAP system for the synthesis of N‑butyl‑5-methylpyrrolidinone (NBPO) and N‑butyl‑5-methylpyrrolidine (NBPE) comparing its catalytic performances with catalysts prepared with moderately or marked acidic supports such as CuO/SiO2 and CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 to investigate the influence of the acid-base nature of the support on the catalytic activity and selectivity. 2 Results and discussion The efficacy of supported copper catalysts in reactions involving carbonyl group activation [22–24] and amine-coupling has already been reported. In particular, Cu/Al2O3 resulted to enable the synthesis of amines starting from ketones [25] or alcohols [26]. Moreover, we already reported the effectiveness of supported copper catalysts in lactam synthesis, starting from biobased lactones, using heterogeneous copper catalysts supported on amphotheric Al2O3 materials. The results enlightened the importance of copper morphology in diverting the catalyst activity and selectivity that can be tuned by choosing the support with the appropriate features. Considering these achievements, the amination of γ-valerolactone with butylamine to obtain N‑butyl‑5-methylpyrrolidinone (NBPO) as the main product was studied in the present paper using similar materials. Copper was initially deposited on three different supports: one amphoteric, namely hydroxyapatite (HAP) (see Supporting information for acid base characterization of HAP), one acidic, namely SiO2-Al2O3 and one moderately acidic, namely SiO2, to study the influence of the support acid-base properties on the catalytic reaction outcome. The catalysts were prepared by depositing copper on each support by the Chemisorption-Hydrolysis method and tested in the lactamization of GVL with butylamine. The optimized reaction conditions were found to be T = 200 °C, P(H2) = 10 bar and GVL: BuNH2 molar ratio of 1:1. The materials were tested up to 6 h of reaction when the conversion and yield of the products reached a plateau. In fact, carrying out the reaction for a longer time (up to 24 h) did not significantly improve the catalytic performances. The reactions were performed under a hydrogen atmosphere to prevent catalysts deactivation [14]. The comparison of the three catalytic systems resulted in data reported in Fig. 1 . The materials showed different performances in terms of activity and selectivity and CuO/HAP was found to be the most active catalyst with the highest selectivity towards the green solvent NBPO, reaching a conversion of 77 % of GVL and a yield in NBPO of about 50 %. On the other hand, CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 shows poor activity while CuO/SiO2 despite a quite poor conversion gives a higher content in the deoxygenated product NBPE. Therefore, we explored the possibility to use amines other than the butyl one by comparing the behaviour of CuO/SiO2 and CuO/HAP. The reaction protocol resulted to be extended to other amines with the same trend in selectivity comparing the two systems Cu/SiO2 and Cu/HAP, that means with higher yield in the N-alkyl-5-methylpyrrolidine (NAPE) and in N-alkyl-5-methylpyrrolidinone (NAPO) respectively (Table 1 ). As a general observation when using bulkier amines than Bu-NH2, such as cyclohexylamine, hexylamine and benzylamine, the formation of the diamine as by-product was also observed, thus suggesting the opportunity to optimise the reaction protocol to improve the conversion. Nonetheless the results obtained show the possibility to extend the lactamization to other kind of reactants, thus expanding the possible synthetic application to more complex structures useful as scaffold in the organic synthesis. To verify the stability of the system in both the lactamization and the hydrogenation and the possible effect of poisoning due to the presence of the amine, recycling experiments have been carried out with CuO/SiO2 (Fig. 2 ). Data reported show a pretty good stability of the catalyst, that despite a loss in activity especially after the first run, completely preserves its selectivity towards the two amination products. This result is significant considering the reaction conditions and the presence of amines as reagents and the simple recycling protocol. The experiments were carried out just by filtering the reaction mixture, washing the solid with the reaction solvent, drying it overnight at 120 °C and charging a fresh mixture, thus leaving room for improvement for the best catalyst reuse conditions. To relate the bulk and surface features of the catalysts with the catalytic performances, a deep physical-chemical characterization was carried out. The sample textural properties, such as specific surface area (SSA) and pore volume (PV), and the copper loading determined by Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) analyses are shown in Table 2 . To have an outlook of the copper morphology TEM micrographs of the samples were acquired. CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 (Fig. 3 ) showed a bimodal Cu nanoparticle size distribution. The micrographs enlightened the co-presence of two different particle populations: one between 1.7 and 6 nm with a mean value of 3.2 nm (40 % ca of the population) and another one with a broader distribution of larger size, between 9 and 30 nm. Moreover, larger nanoparticles >30 nm up to 70 nm size were also identified. On the other hand, CuO/HAP (Fig. 3, bottom) presented a very different nanoparticle morphology: the nanoparticles were much smaller (estimated mean value 2–3 nm) and very well dispersed. A similar situation was found for CuO/SiO2 as enlightened by STEM micrographs, which showed the presence of highly dispersed small Cu nanoparticles of mean size value of 2.4 nm [27]. To investigate the coordination environment of the copper species on the catalyst surfaces, UV–vis Diffuse Reflectance (UV-DR) spectra were recorded in the 200–1200 cm-1 range. Due to their enlargement, absorption bands were deconvoluted to understand the different speciation contributions and the spectra and the deconvolution results are shown in Fig. 4 . The UV-DR spectra of the samples presented two main absorption bands, one with a peak around 270 cm-1 and one broader in the range 600–1400 cm-1. According to the literature, the first one can be ascribed to the ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (Cu2+ ← O2-) [28]. After deconvolution, some other contribution bands can be acknowledged. In the case of the CuO/SiO2, it can be observed a small band at 220 cm-1 that could be ascribed to the presence of some Cu+ [29]. It is also noticeable, in the case of CuO/HAP, a contribution band at 403 cm-1 that indicates the presence of Cu+ in three dimensional clusters in the CuO matrix [28,30]. The presence of Cu+ could be ascribable to the electron-rich environment produced by the phosphate groups that could partially cause the reduction of the Cu2+. The large absorption band from 600 to 1400 cm-1 is assigned to d-d (2Eg → 2T2 g) transitions of Cu2+ located in more or less tetragonally distorted octahedral environment with an distorted Oh symmetry. Moreover, this band is shifted to lower wavelength with a more distorted symmetry [28,31]. As observable, the band presents two components at different wavelengths if we compare the catalysts. In the case of CuO/SiO2 the bands are at lower wavenumbers, meaning that the CuO presents a quite distorted symmetry with a contribution of square pyramid valency (870 cm-1) [28]. On the other hand, the other two samples display a higher contribution at wavelengths >950 cm-1 suggesting an increase in crystallinity and the formation of bulk CuO, that it is also in agreement with a higher Cu loading shown by the samples. In any case, both CuO/SiO2 and CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 present a shoulder at 1400 cm-1 typical of the tetrahedral symmetry. Copper reducibility was investigated by Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) to have more information about the copper morphology and reducibility; the obtained profiles are shown in Fig. 5 . The Tmax is displayed in the inset table in Fig. 4. The three materials presented a remarkably different reduction behaviour. The CuO/SiO2 catalyst presents a sharp peak centred at around 242 °C that can be ascribed to the reduction of a well dispersed and highly uniform single CuO phase into Cu(0) that was already observed in the case of copper catalysts prepared with the CH method [32]. On the other hand, CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 sample presents a broader peak centred at around 287 °C with a shoulder at around 267 °C, indicating a copper phase less prone to be reduced. This reduction profile was coherent with the bimodal size distribution found through TEM analysis: the two reduction events could be ascribed to the two different particle size population. This was also in accordance with previous results showing that on CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 prepared with CH method, Cu isolated ions likely belonging to a surface Cu-aluminate-like phase and strongly resistant to reduction were observed, while on SiO2 small and well dispersed CuO particles were formed [33]. In fact, an explanation of the higher reduction temperature values could be due to the electron-withdrawing capacity of aluminium that hampers the copper reduction. An even different situation was found for the CuO/HAP sample: the reduction profile presents one broad peak centred at 192 °C with one shoulder at around 250 °C once again diagnostic of the presence of two well dispersed copper species [34]. The lower reduction temperature peak could be ascribable to the presence of Cu+ clusters in the CuO matrix that was also detected in the UV DRs spectrum. In both CuO/HAP and CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 cases, this phenomenon could be due to a strong interaction between the copper species and the support [33]. To understand the surface acidic features of the samples, two different characterization techniques have been used, namely FT-IR after pyridine adsorption and liquid-solid acid-base titration using phenylethylamine (PEA) as basic probe molecule.໿ Liquid-solid acid-base titration of the samples using PEA probe was carried out in the reaction solvent, n-heptane, to have a clue of the effective acidity. Two titration runs were performed. The first run quantifies the total amount of acid sites saturating the surface with PEA; the second run gives account for the weak acid sites obtained through a new titration after desorption of physisorbed PEA (Fig. 6 ). The difference in adsorbed PEA between the two runs is therefore related to the number of strong acid sites (Table 3 ). FT-IR after pyridine adsorption is useful to discriminate between the nature of the acidic sites, namely Brønsted and Lewis ones, and to quantify them. Bands around 1450 cm−1 and 1610 cm−1 can be ascribed to pyridine bounded to Lewis acid sites, while absorption at 1550 cm−1 together with peaks near 1620 cm−1 and 1640 cm−1 are related to the presence of Brønsted acid sites [35]. CuO/HAP presented some issues during the experiment of pyridine adsorption. In fact, HAP materials present an high surface concentration of CO3 2-, which absorbs in the 1600-1400 cm-1 region [36], that is the same of the pyridine adsorbed on the acidic sites present onto a solid surface. To overcome this problem, CuO/HAP was dispersed with a non-acidic matrix such as pyrogenic SiO2, to limit the signal of carbonates absorption band. The FT-IR spectra after pyridine adsorption of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 . The samples show the presence of Lewis acidic sites as expected from the copper catalysts prepared with the CH method [32]. Brønsted sites, that are typical of HAP and SiO2-Al2O3, are no longer present or just in negligible amounts in the case of CuO/SiO2-Al2O3. Interestingly, CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 and CuO/HAP after deconvolution, present two contributions in the 1610 cm-1 region. This could be due to the presence of two different Lewis sites centres, namely Al and Cu in the case of CuO/SiO2 -Al2O3 and Ca and Cu for CuO/HAP. A similar behaviour was observed by some of us in the spectra of SiO2-Al2O3 and CuO/SiO2-Al2O3: the support presented a Lewis band at 1623 cm-1 deriving from Al3+, while the copper catalyst presented also a band at 1610 cm-1 ascribable to Cu centres [37]. According to the quantification method proposed by Emeis [35], the integration of the characteristic Lewis band is normalized for the mass of the sample disk. Notably, CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 presented the highest number of acidic sites followed by CuO/HAP and CuO/SiO2 (Inset table of Fig. 7, first column). However, if the acid site density is considered (Inset table of Fig. 7, second column), CuO/HAP consistently presented higher acidic sites on the surface compared to the other samples. This is due to the presence of many functional groups exposed on a considerably low surface area. However, it is possible to note a shift to lower wavelength of the Lewis band from 1611 cm-1 to 1609 cm-1 and 1595 cm-1 for CuO/SiO2 -Al2O3, CuO/SiO2, and CuO/HAP respectively. This could be a symptom of the acid sites strength: a lower wavelength associated with a lower strength of the site [37,38]. This is in agreement with the strong acid sites quantification ranking obtained from titration with PEA. The reasons for the different catalytic activity of the materials could be searched in the surface properties. The role of Lewis acid sites is pivotal in promoting both activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of carbonyl compounds [22–24]. Thus, they can coordinate with the Lewis basic CO group via one of the oxygen lone pairs, activating the GVL to the amine nucleophilic attack. CuO/HAP and CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 show to be markedly acidic when analysed both in-vacuum after pyridine adsorption and in solvent with PEA titration with the contribution of both Ca2+ and Cu2+ and Al3+ and Cu2+ in imparting Lewis acidity, respectively. These elements ensure high catalytic activity: a proper amount of acidity is fundamental in activating the CO group of GVL towards the nucleophilic attack of the amine. However, CuO/HAP presented weaker acidic sites compared to CuO/SiO2-Al2O3. In this respect we suggest that a weaker acidity of the copper sites could prevent a strong amine-copper adsorption, responsible for the formation of nitride species that poison the catalytic active sites [39]. A clue can be found in a faster deactivation of the CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts, reaching a plateau in conversion just after 4 h of reaction. Besides, the presence of smaller and well dispersed Cu nanoparticles present on CuO/HAP could be the reason for its higher activity. Some considerations about the mechanism involved can be also done based on the Lewis acid character and on the hydrogen transfer capacity of this class of copper catalysts. As already mentioned, very few examples of catalytic lactamization of lactones are reported in the literature and they mainly rely on the use of homogeneous systems such as Iridium complexes [40] or ZrOCl2 [41]. These studies propose different mechanisms for the synthesis of lactams starting from lactones and amines. Hong and co-workers proposed a pathway promoted by [cp*IrCl2]2 starting with the formation of the hydroxyamide, followed by the addition of a second amine molecule to obtain an aminoamide that by means of a transamidation step gives the desired lactam thanks to a hydrogen autotransfer step [40]. On the other hand, when using a Lewis acid such as ZrOCl2, a mechanism involving the formation of hydroxyamide followed by the direct cyclization via intramolecular nucleophilic substitution into the lactam is proposed [41]. Under our conditions a process that traces the latter route is likely the most probable one. Under our reaction conditions, namely 10 atm of H2 and 200 °C we did not observe the formation of any intermediate, but some intriguing clues can be drawn by carrying out the reaction under nitrogen, considering that in principle the formation of pyrrolidinone would not need the presence of H2. Nonetheless. under inert atmosphere after 24 h reaction, only 20 % of GVL conversion was observed, with the formation of the products shown in Scheme 2 identified by GC–MS analysis. These results can be explained by the dehydrogenation of the hydroxyamide derived from lactone ring opening; the following cyclisation gives the unsaturated pyrrolidinone that in turn can be reduced thanks to hydrogen made available by the dehydrogenation step. The suggested mechanism is coherent with those proposed in the literature for LA [42] and for EL [43]. Moreover the pyrrolidinone structure partially undergoes the addition of another amine molecule. The dehydrogenation/hydrogenation activity for this kind of catalysts has already been exploited for other synthetic applications [44]. Although this kind of reactivity would not be favoured under hydrogen, a possible contribution to the overall process cannot be excluded also under the reaction conditions used in the present work. On the other hand, CuO/SiO2 presented a lower acidic sites density according to both the characterization techniques. In this case, this could be detrimental for the catalytic activity of the material. Nevertheless, despite being the less active material, CuO/SiO2 was the most selective towards product NBPE namely the deoxygenated one. This result is consistent with the high activity of silica supported copper catalyst in the deoxygenation of aromatic ketones reported in a previous work [45]. In the same investigation Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 already revealed not to be a suitable catalyst for this transformation also in the absence of an aminic reagent, thus confirming the inactivity of this system in the hydrodeoxygenation step. The fine tuning of the copper phase has shown to be a pivotal tool in achieving high activity in the selective hydrogenation of this substrate [46]. Despite starting from the unreduced CuO/SiO2 its high selectivity towards the deoxygenated product could be ascribed to the presence on lone Cu sites centres. Besides their moderately Lewis acidic character, copper centers are also more prone to be reduced from Cu(II) to Cu(0) in situ by the reaction hydrogen atmosphere as confirmed by the TPR analysis above described. To have a deeper insight into this aspect, the activity of the same catalysts in the direct reduction of a lactam was tested. It is worth underlining that the catalytic deoxygenative hydrogenation of lactams into the corresponding cyclic amines is a not trivial reaction, although of fundamental importance in the organic synthesis. Heterogeneous catalysts usually request demanding hydrogenation conditions and the main systems reported rely on the use of homogeneous noble metal-based complexes [47]. The copper-based catalysts described in the present work have been tested in the deoxygenation of ε-caprolactam obtaining a conversion trend CuO/SiO2 > CuO/HAP > CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 with a yield in the corresponding amine after 6 h of 20 % obtained with the silica supported catalysts vs the 8 % and 4 % of CuO/HAP and CuO/SiO2-Al2O3 respectively. Results reported corroborate the main conclusions about the reduction capacity ranking already observed in the direct amination of GVL, that was found to be. The last one confirmed to be almost inactive in the hydrogenation of the CO group of the lactam, This evidence not only confirms the different behaviour of the dispersed metal phase upon the nature of the support, but also paves the way to a wider range of synthetic application of this class of catalysts and particularly the possibility to properly chose the support upon the desired reaction pathway. All the above described and analysed features strongly contribute to the design of catalytic systems allowing to preferentially address the selectivity towards the pyrrolidinone or alternatively to the pyrrolidine products. 3 Conclusions Copper catalysts supported over HAP and SiO2 by a simple chemisorption-hydrolysis method can be conveniently used for the preparation of N-containing molecules starting from γ-valerolactone and butylamine. The system supported over HAP favours the formation of N‑butyl‑5-methyl-pyrrolidinone, while the system supported over SiO2 is more selective to the formation of the corresponding deoxygenated pyrrolidine. The main reasons for this behaviour can be ascribed to copper dispersion, morphology and acid features of the catalysts obtained, thus revealing the possibility to address the reaction course by tailoring the surface properties of the catalytic systems and in particular to exploit HAP as versatile material for catalytic purposes. The preparation of NBPO starting from γ-valerolactone and butylamine under mild conditions with the use of a non-noble based catalyst is an important step towards the upgrading of biomass derived platform molecules into N-containing structures. NBPO is in fact considered one of the promising alternative green solvents to the widely used toxic NMP. 4 Experimental section 4.1 Materials SiO2 was obtained by Evonik, SiO2-Al2O3 (Alumina content 13.5 %) was purchased from Merck. γ-valerolactone (GVL) with purity 99 %, n-butylamine, cyclohexylamine, hexylamine and benzylamine with purity 99 %, copper nitrate trihydrate with purity 99 % heptane (purity >99 %) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Stoichiometric hydroxyapatite (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2, atom/atom Ca/P ratio equal to 1.67) has been synthesized utilizing a coprecipitation method. A 0.1 M aqueous solution of (NH4)2HPO4 (250 ml) was placed in a three-necked round flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer, a reflux condenser and an adaptor for peristaltic pump tube connection. The (NH4)2HPO4 solution was heated to 80 °C under stirring (200 rpm) through an oil bath and pH was adjusted to 9.7 adding 50 ml of a 28–30 % wt/wt NH4OH solution. Subsequently, 250 mL of a 0.167 M aqueous solution of Ca(NO3)2·4H2O were fed to the flask through a peristaltic pump (dropping rate = 1.5 mL min¬1). During the addition, the pH of the solution was kept constant. All solutions were prepared from MilliQ water (15.0 MΩ, Millipore). Addition of the Ca(II) precursor solution leads to the formation of a milky suspension. HAP precipitates according to the following chemical equation: 10 Ca(NO3)2 + 6 (NH4)2HPO4 + 8NH3 + 2H2O → Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2 ↓ + 20 (NH4)NO3 Catalysts were prepared using the Chemisorption-Hydrolysis (CH) method [32]. The supports (SiO2, SiO2-Al2O3 and HAP) were added into to an aqueous [Cu(NH3)4]2+ solution prepared by dropping NH4OH to a Cu(NO3)2·3H2O solution (25 mL) with the desired concentration until pH 9 had been reached. After 20 min under stirring, the slurry was diluted with 3 L of water in an ice bath at 0 °C. The solid was separated by filtration with a Büchner funnel, washed with water, dried overnight at 110 °C and calcined in air atmosphere at 350 °C for 4 h General procedure for GVL lactamization: Before any reaction the catalysts (100 mg) were pre-treated for 20 min at 270 °C under air and for 20 min under vacuum and then reduced through three hydrogen (1 bar) and vacuum cycles (5 mins each) at the same temperature. Then the catalyst (100 mg) was suspended in the reaction solvent (10 ml) and loaded 100 mL Parr reactor together with the GVL (100 mg) and the amine (1 equivalent). Then, the autoclave was pressurized with H2 (10 atm) or N2 (6 atm) and the temperature was brought to 200 °C for 2 h under magnetic stirring (750 rpm). Reaction conversions and selectivity were determined by GC-FID analysis using an Agilent 6890 Gas 0,25 Chromatography system with a Alltech Heliflex AT-5 capillary column. Dodecane was used as internal standard (carbon balance >98 %). Products were qualitative determined with GCMS– analysis using an Agilent 5957C GC–MS chromatograph with an HP-5 column. Conversion was determined using the following equation: % C = n ( t 0 ) − n ( t ) n ( t 0 ) The selectivity of the products was calculated using the following equation: % S = n p Σ n × 100 Where np are the moles of the considered product and Σn is the sum of the moles of each formed products determined with GC-FID analysis. For the recycling experiments after 3 h the reaction mixture was cooled down and filtered. The catalyst was therefore washed with heptane, dried overnight at 120 °C and the reused without any other pretreatment. Specific Surface Area and Porosity: SSA and PV were determined by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms collected at −196 °C using automatic analysers of surface area Micromeritics ASAP 2020 (V4.02). Prior to the analysis, the sample, was outgassed at 350 °C for 4 h under vacuum to remove water and other volatile organic compounds adsorbed on the surface. Specific surface area values were calculated by Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation. Pore volume (PV), pore size and pore size distribution were determined by Barrett-Joyner- Halenda (BJH) model from the desorption branch of the collected isotherms. Liquid-solid acid-base titrations with PEA: The acid-base liquid-solid titrations on the samples were performed using 2-phenylethylamine (PEA, pKa = 9.90) as a probe in different solvents namely cyclohexane and heptane (aprotic-apolar), CPME and dioxane (both aprotic-polar). The experimental set up consisted in a HPLC line, comprising a pump (Waters, model 515), a reservoir and a monochromatic UV detector (Waters, model 2487, λ = 254 nm), coupled to a personal computer for the collection, storage, and processing of the data. The sample (0.050–0.100 g, crushed and sieved as 80–200 mesh particles) was placed in a small stainless tubular sample holder between two sand pillows. The sample was successively activated at 350 °C for 16 h in flowing air (8 mL min-1), then evacuated and eventually filled with the operating solvent. The sample holder, inserted in a glass jacket connected with a water thermostat to maintain a constant temperature (± 0.1 °C), was placed instead of the chromatographic column. The titrations were carried out by injecting successive dosed amounts of PEA in the operating solvents (20 50 mL, 0.10 0.15 M) into the line in which the solution continuously circulated. For each injection, the PEA solution recirculated onto the sample until adsorption equilibrium was achieved, revealed by the attainment of the UV-detector signal stability. Assuming a 1:1 stoichiometry for the PEA adsorption on the acid site, the number of acid sites per sample mass titrated at each equilibrium PEA concentration was evaluated, obtaining adsorption isotherms for the various samples. During the first run, the injections of PEA solution were done until surface saturation; then, clean solvent was flowed through the sample to remove the physisorbed PEA, and the second run adsorption was collected. Subtraction of the second run from the first gives the chemisorption isotherm, from which the strong acid sites can be computed. Total amount of acidic sites and strong acidic sites per mass of solvent were obtained through Langmuir linearization model of the experimental adsorption isotherms. Infrared Spectroscopy: The Fourier Transform-Infrared (FT-IR) studies of the adsorption of the pyridine probe molecule were carried out on a Nicolet iS50 FT-IR purchased from Thermo Scientific. The experiments were performed in all cases except for CuO/HAP sample on a thin disk of sample (20–30 mg, pressed at 1–2 tons) after a reduction pre-treatment consisting in 20 min at 270° at air followed by 20 min at 270 °C under vacuum and finally a reduction under H2 through three hydrogen (1 bar) and vacuum cycle at the same temperature. The first spectrum was collected before pyridine adsorption as a blank and it was subtracted to each spectrum prior to data curation. Then, pyridine vapors were adsorbed at room temperature and then desorbed in steps of 30 min until 250 °C at the given vacuum (10–5 bar). The spectrum of each desorption step was collected every 50 °C up to 250 °C. For quantitative analysis the amount of absorbed pyridine (mmolpy gcat −1) was calculated on the basis of the relationship reported by Emeis [35]. CuO/HAP sample was prepared dispersing the catalysts in an inert, non-acidic matrix, namely SiO2 A, in a mass ratio of 1:15 wt/wt. This mixed powder was pressed and pre-treated and analyzed with the same procedure of the other sample. This had the aim to limit the CO3 2- signal which absorbs in the 1600–1400 cm-1 region. Emeis equations were still applied but W was only the weight of CuO/HAP contained in the disk. The Lewis site band at 1600 cm-1 was deconvoluted and fitted by using a Gaussian function. UV–vis Diffuse Reflectance Spectroscopy: Spectra were collected at room temperature in 200–2600 nm interval through a double beam UV–vis–NIR scanning spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-3600 plus, Japan) equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory (integrating sphere from BIS-603). Each sample was pretreated in oven (110 °C) overnight and finely ground, uniformly pressed in a circular disk (diameter of ca. 4 cm) and placed in the sample-holder. This was inserted in a special quartz cuvette and placed on the window of the integrating sphere for reflectance measurements. Spectra were measured using ultrafine spectroscopy standard BaSO4 as the reference. The measured reflectance values (R∞,%) were converted to absorbance (Abs, a.u.) by the equation: Abs = Log ( 1 / R ∞ / 100 ) To discriminate each contribution the collected UV–vis-DR spectra (Absorbance, a.u., vs. wavelength, nm) in 200–1800 nm and 200–800 nm ranges were deconvoluted using a two contribution peaks type Gaussian method. Inductive Coupled Plasma Analysis: Cu loading of the catalysts samples was determined by ICP-OES, AAS, and IC analyses by means of an «Activa », Jobin Yvon ICP-OES instrument, or a PinAAcle 900T, S/N PTDS11062202, Perkin Elmer, Waltham, MA, USA, or a Dionex DX-120 instrument. It was double checked both on digested solids (ca. 50 mg of sample treated in concentrated HNO3 for each analysis), and on the filtration solutions. In particular, IC analyses were carried out by means of an IonPac CS5A analytical column from Dionex, using a solution of 50 mM oxalic acid/95 mM lithium hydroxide (pH 4.8) as eluent, and a solution of 0.4 mM PAR in 3 M NH4OH and 1 M acetic acid as colorimetric indicator for UV–vis detection (at 520 nm) of metal ions (reagent flow rate of 0.6 mL min-1). Calibration lines for Cu determination were built by analyzing standard solutions with concentration in 1–10 ppm interval prepared by a commercial multistandard certified by Areachem. Temperature programmed reduction: TPR was performed with a modified version of the Pulse Chemisorb 2700 apparatus from Micromeritics. Catalysts (samples containing ca. 2 mg of Cu) were diluted with quartz, calcined at 300 °C under O2 (40 mL/min) with a thermal program consisting in: i) heating 10 °C/min until 300 °C ii) hold the temperature for 60 min. After calcination, catalysts were reduced at 8 °C/min under a flow (15 mL/ min) of a 8 % H2/Ar mixture. The H2 consumption was detected by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). coredata.dc:description: The rich functionalities of platform molecules derived from the lignocellulosic deconstruction stream prompt their upgrading into valuable molecules and in particular into N-containing ones. Heterogeneous copper catalysts properly tailored with the right choice of the support, can effectively promote the amination of γ-valerolactone into the corresponding N-alkyl-pyrrolidinone or N-alkyl-pyrrolidines. The acidic properties and the copper phase morphology and dispersion are critical aspects to be investigated to address the reaction selectivity. The proposed transformation allows to obtain nitrogen derivatives that can find application as green solvents or as scaffolds for the chemical synthesis.
coredata.dc:title: Tailoring the surface properties of supported copper catalysts to address GVL amination selectivity
